citations.narrative:
The licensee did not follow the Program of Veterinary Care related to the administration of anti-parasitic drugs for
intestinal parasites to adult dogs. The Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 1/7/2022, called for the
administration of Fenbendazole twice per year (approximately 6 months apart) and the administration of toltrazuril twice a
year (approximately 6 months apart). The Fenbendazole and Toltrazuril administration were to be separated from each
other by approximately 3 months. However, the licensee stated that he was administering both the fenbendazole and the
toltrazuril medication to the adult females after whelping, at the time he was administering these medications to the
puppies. Therefore, the adult females were receiving both the fenbendazole and the toltrazuril anti-parasitic medications
within about 4 to 6 weeks of each other.
Failure to follow the Program of Veterinary Care can lead to harm to the animals from the inappropriate administration of
medication or the development of illnesses that the Program of Veterinary Care is meant to prevent.
The licensee must follow the Program of Veterinary Care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by
the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by close of business on 12/30/2024.

Certain medical records were not maintained for dogs sold and held by the licensee. The written Program of Veterinary
Care, signed and dated 1/7/2022, required yearly vaccination of adult dogs with a 5-way vaccine (Distemper, Adenovirus
1 & 2, Parvovirus, & Parainfluenza), monthly administration of heartworm prevention, and a detailed weekly preventative
health care exam (which includes examination of the eyes, ears, skin, teeth, nails, & haircoat). The licensee stated that he
was administering the yearly 5-way vaccination, giving the monthly heartworm prevention, and performing the weekly
preventive health care checks; however, he sometimes neglected to document these activities. At the time of the
inspection, there were no records of yearly 5-way vaccination of adult dogs, there were no records of administration of
heartworm prevention in the month of June 2024, and there were no records of weekly preventive health care exams in
the month of October 2024.
Medical records are essential for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of medical care provided by the facility and
ensure the animals are protected from disease, injury, and illness.
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These
records must include routine husbandry procedures (such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, and
treatments) performed an all animals.
To be corrected by the close of business on 11/8/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee did not follow the Program of Veterinary Care related to the administration of anti-parasitic drugs for 
intestinal parasites to adult dogs. The Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 1/7/2022, called for the 
administration of Fenbendazole twice per year (approximately 6 months apart) and the administration of toltrazuril twice a 
year (approximately 6 months apart). The Fenbendazole and Toltrazuril administration were to be separated from each 
other by approximately 3 months. However, the licensee stated that he was administering both the fenbendazole and the 
toltrazuril medication to the adult females after whelping, at the time he was administering these medications to the 
puppies. Therefore, the adult females were receiving both the fenbendazole and the toltrazuril anti-parasitic medications 
within about 4 to 6 weeks of each other. 
 
Failure to follow the Program of Veterinary Care can lead to harm to the animals from the inappropriate administration of 
medication or the development of illnesses that the Program of Veterinary Care is meant to prevent. 
 
The licensee must follow the Program of Veterinary Care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by 
the attending veterinarian.  
 
To be corrected by close of business on 12/30/2024. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Certain medical records were not maintained for dogs sold and held by the licensee. The written Program of Veterinary 
Care, signed and dated 1/7/2022, required yearly vaccination of adult dogs with a 5-way vaccine (Distemper, Adenovirus 
1 & 2, Parvovirus, & Parainfluenza), monthly administration of heartworm prevention, and a detailed weekly preventative 
health care exam (which includes examination of the eyes, ears, skin, teeth, nails, & haircoat). The licensee stated that he 
was administering the yearly 5-way vaccination, giving the monthly heartworm prevention, and performing the weekly 
preventive health care checks; however, he sometimes neglected to document these activities. At the time of the 
inspection, there were no records of yearly 5-way vaccination of adult dogs, there were no records of administration of 
heartworm prevention in the month of June 2024, and there were no records of weekly preventive health care exams in 
the month of October 2024.

Medical records are essential for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of medical care provided by the facility and 
ensure the animals are protected from disease, injury, and illness. 
 
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These 
records must include routine husbandry procedures (such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, and 
treatments) performed an all animals.  
 
To be corrected by the close of business on 11/8/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
